The evidence of scientific manuscripts, such et postea prendite quod est desubtum· adobament de'parte· et respice as Harley 5402, does not seem to have been exploited by Italian philologists. The mixed Latin pres· qualis'partem· est de .Ix., e'prendite talis partem de'circulo minor· e'gun- and Italian of our annotator recalls the kind of language that merchants used in their letters, according to Boncompagno writing in 1215 (apud Migliorini, Storia, p.91): 'Mercatores in suis gite· ad adobament de'parte· et istum gungime<n>t· abet nomen adobament· epistolis verborum ornatum non requirunt, quia fere omnes et singuli per idiomata propria seu di' ueritatem· vulgaria vel corruptum latinum ad invicem sibi scribunt et rescribunt'. respice partem lune· si' est minus de .vi .. S., tollite adobbament di' ueritatem 14 It is interesting to note that one of the most substantial documents written in Italian in the di'medius cursum lune· et si'plus est parte de .vi. S., gungite adobamentum di'ueri- twelfth century is a religious poem written by a Jew in Hebrew script; see Migliorini, Storia, tatem supra medium cursu m lune· et ohc est locum lune
